title: Understanding Postmenopausal Bleeding
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value: Postmenopausal bleeding is any vaginal bleeding that occurs after menopause.

items: Menopause is confirmed after 12 months without a period (if not using hormonal contraception that affects bleeding)
Any vaginal bleeding after this time is unusual and should be checked
Many causes are benign, but postmenopausal bleeding can sometimes be a sign of cancer or other conditions that need treatment

content.value: Postmenopausal bleeding is a relatively common reason for medical review.,Most women who experience bleeding after menopause have a benign (non-cancerous) cause, such as thinning of the vaginal tissues or the womb lining.,However, a small number of cases may be linked to cancer of the womb (endometrial cancer), which is why prompt assessment is important.
Bleeding may range from light spotting or brown discharge to heavier bleeding.

items: Vaginal or endometrial atrophy (thinning of tissues after menopause)

Many women with postmenopausal bleeding have no other symptoms. However, depending on the cause, you may notice:

items: Urinary symptoms (such as frequency or urgency)
Feeling tired or weak if bleeding has been ongoing

sections.cardTitle: Risk Factors for Postmenopausal Bleeding Causes

content.value: Some factors increase the chance of conditions linked to postmenopausal bleeding, particularly endometrial (womb) problems.

items: Family history of endometrial, ovarian, or colorectal cancer (especially Lynch syndrome)
Use of oestrogen-only HRT (without progesterone in women with a womb)

content.value: These tests are often done as outpatient procedures.

items.title: Medical History and Pelvic Exam
items.content: Your doctor will ask about your symptoms, medications, and medical history, and may perform a pelvic exam.

items.title: Transvaginal Ultrasound
items.content: A small probe is placed in the vagina to look at the uterus and measure the thickness of the womb lining (endometrium). This helps identify abnormalities.

items.title: Hysteroscopy
items.content: A thin camera is passed through the cervix to look inside the womb. A small tissue sample (biopsy) is often taken to check for abnormal cells.

items.title: Cervical screening (if due)
items.content: This may be done as routine screening, but it does not explain most causes of postmenopausal bleeding.

content.value: Contact your doctor promptly if you experience following symptoms.

items: Bleeding that is heavier than spotting or keeps happening
Bleeding with pelvic pain or unusual discharge
Ongoing tiredness or unexplained weight loss

content.title: Seek urgent medical help if you have:
content.description: Very heavy bleeding (soaking pads quickly or passing large clots), Severe abdominal or pelvic pain, Fever or feeling unwell with bleeding, Dizziness, fainting, or signs of blood loss
